description: Daria Tomenko, moved by increasing assembly demands and her brother's erasure, decides to unlock and release the encrypted BCI and Council records, bypassing old clearance barriers.
A trove of BCI logs and Council archives is published across networks and assembly forums. Evidence of abuses and systemic manipulation becomes available citywide, provoking intense public debate.
Open assemblies convene in districts as residents scrutinize the released records, openly confronting former technocrats and BCI operators about their roles in past injustices.
Consensus-based judgment sessions begin, with communities debating, annulling, or reintegrating compliance histories. Surviving Council members are required to answer directly to public accusations.
The citywide Mosaic Manifesto is adopted, formally rejecting algorithmic governance. District celebrations mark the end of BCI-era authority and return of political life to the citizenry.
